item.title: Anthropic Internal AI Development Survey: Frontend Shines, Architecture Is Hardest to Hand Off to AI
item.content:encoded:
Introduction: Is AI Really Making Engineers More Productive?

Section titled â€œIntroduction: Is AI Really Making Engineers More Productive?â€

This year, every developer friend around me keeps asking the same question:

â€œI use Claude/Copilot every day, but is it really worth it? Are the vendors overselling me?â€

Coincidentally, Anthropic turned the real usage data of 132 internal engineers and researchers into a detailed survey and interviews, plus several charts.

It is like an AI vendor giving itself a physical exam. Who is delighted, who is stumblingâ€”everything is written in the numbers.

Letâ€™s look at the report from a working engineerâ€™s perspective and talk about: In software engineering, which tasks have the highest ROI with AI, and which ones should you not rush to offload to a model?

I. What Kind of Internal Survey Is This?

Section titled â€œI. What Kind of Internal Survey Is This?â€

Anthropic asked 132 engineers and researchers a series of very concrete questions:

  • How much of your daily work do you do with Claude?
  • What do you mainly use it for? Debugging, new features, refactoring, tests, documentation, or design and planning?
  • For each task type, does working with Claude make you spend more or less time?
  • Does the volume of output (code, docs, deliverables) go up or down?

They also compared changes over time:

  • A year ago, employees estimated that about 28% of their work used Claude, self-reporting a +20% productivity lift.
  • Now that number has risen to 59% of work done with Claude, with an average self-reported productivity +50%; around 14% of â€œpower usersâ€ believe they improved by over 100%.

Another independent study is also striking: using 100,000 real conversations, Anthropic estimated that the median task completion time dropped by roughly 80%.

It sounds dramatic, but engineers know self-reported productivity needs a haircut. The more useful takeaway is: by task type, where are the real gains and where is the fluff?

II. Overall Pattern: Time Saved Is Small, Output Gain Is Big

Section titled â€œII. Overall Pattern: Time Saved Is Small, Output Gain Is Bigâ€

That figure you saw is one of the core findings:

  • Left: after using Claude, for a given task, time spent goes down, stays the same, or goes up.
  • Right: in the same amount of time, the amount of output goes up by how much.

Looking across all tasks, two patterns stand out:

  1. For most tasks, time is only slightly lower

    • Many points sit around â€œ-1â€ (a light decrease).
    • It means people are saving a little, not cutting the time in half.

  2. But the output increase is more obvious

    • In the right plot, most points are in the â€œ+1 to +2â€ range.
    • So even when time only drops a bit, the amount produced jumps a lot.

A hidden detail: In the raw data, a small group actually spends more time on some tasks.

Their interview explanations feel very real:

  • Cleaning up after Claudeâ€”fixing the mess it made, redoing debugging and cleanup.
  • Spending time to understand code they did not write themselves.
  • Or because Claude exists, they simply work more thoroughly: more tests, more exploration.

In short:

Time does not vanish; it gets â€œreinvestedâ€ into more work.

III. ROI by Task Type: Frontend Wins, Design and Infra Lose

Section titled â€œIII. ROI by Task Type: Frontend Wins, Design and Infra Loseâ€

Looking at the distribution and my own experience, the ROI ranking is clear.

1) ROI Ceiling: Frontend, New Features, Debugging, Testing, Documentation

Section titled â€œ1) ROI Ceiling: Frontend, New Features, Debugging, Testing, Documentationâ€

These tasks share traits:

  • Outcomes are easy to verify

    • Frontend: run it and you immediately see if the UI is right.
    • Debugging: reproduce the bug, run testsâ€”pass or fail.
    • Tests and docs: format and coverage are obvious at a glance.

  • Task boundaries are clear

    • â€œMake this component responsive.â€
    • â€œAdd a set of unit tests for this code.â€
    • â€œWrite a README for new teammates.â€

In these jobs, the most annoying part for humans is: mechanical, repetitive, boring to write, yet quality is visible instantly.

This matches a keyword Anthropic staff highlighted:

â€œIâ€™m more willing to hand Claude tasks that are easy to verify.â€

The report also notes that engineers increasingly use Claude for frontend visualization, implementing UI, and building small tools, even encouraging backend engineers to write frontend and become â€œquasi full stack.â€

From an ROI lens, these tasks are short, fast projects:

  • Model does the work
  • Human reviews
  • If it breaks, roll back and redo
  • Beginners can supervise

Frontend is a clear beneficiaryâ€”screens, interactions, styles iterate quickly. You focus on user experience itself instead of wrestling with CSS details.

2) Lower ROI: Design and Planning, Infrastructure/DevOps

Section titled â€œ2) Lower ROI: Design and Planning, Infrastructure/DevOpsâ€

On the other end: high-level design, system planning, Infra/DevOps.

Anthropicâ€™s report shows two things:

  • Employees explicitly said:

    • â€œI usually keep high-level thinking and design to myself and hand implementation/debugging tasks to Claude.â€
    • Design and planning tasks show the smallest productivity lift.

  • Infra and DevOps tasks are used less often; time and output gains are limited.

This aligns with software-engineering common sense:

The more a task depends on experience, context, taste, and organizational strategy, the harder it is to fully hand it to AI.

Designing a new system architecture requires considering:

  • What the business looks like in five years
  • The teamâ€™s current stack
  • Who maintains it and who is on-call
  • Cost budget, compliance, and security

Claude can:

  • Generate versions of architecture diagrams
  • List risks and trade-offs
  • Draft design docs

But the person who approves is still you. Here AI is a smart adviser, not the decision-making CTO.

Infra/DevOps is similar:

  • The hard part is

    • Knowing the companyâ€™s complex network topology
    • Dealing with legacy scripts and configs
    • Knowing who owns the pager when things break

  • AI can write scripts, explain logs, draft runbooks.

  • But it is hard to run a command to production without looking.

From an ROI angle:

Frontend, new features, debugging, testing, documentation -> low investment, fast return

Design, planning, Infra -> high value, but AI rarely â€œsaves you a ton of timeâ€ directly

IV. Verifiability: The â€œWatershedâ€ That Decides AI Effectiveness

Section titled â€œIV. Verifiability: The â€œWatershedâ€ That Decides AI Effectivenessâ€

In interviews, Anthropic summarized a pragmatic delegation rule: engineers are more willing to hand Claude tasks that are:

  • Easy to verify
  • Low complexity or clearly bounded
  • Not under extreme quality bars (e.g., one-off debug scripts)
  • Repetitive, dull, but cannot be skipped

This can be abstracted into one word: verifiability.

Think of it this way:

  1. Tasks with tests or demos are great for AI to charge ahead

    • Frontend pages, backend endpoints, data-processing scripts
    • Run them and see whether the result is in the expected range

  2. Tasks relying on â€œtasteâ€ and â€œjudgmentâ€ need human oversight

    • System design, UX design, security strategy
    • Often no standard answers, only trade-offs

  3. Local problems vs. global problems

    • Changing one component or writing a doc is a local problem.
    • Planning a cross-team technical roadmap is a global problem.

Claude delivers huge ROI on local, verifiable tasks. On global, fuzzy tasks, it is better for brainstorming, lists, and comparisons, not for directly giving the final plan.

V. Practical Tips for Typical Teams: Donâ€™t Rush to Make AI the Architect

Section titled â€œV. Practical Tips for Typical Teams: Donâ€™t Rush to Make AI the Architectâ€

If you lead an engineering team or build solo, you can draw a clear â€œsphere of influenceâ€ for AI, following Anthropicâ€™s approach.

1) Start by Treating AI as â€œManual Labor + Recorderâ€

Section titled â€œ1) Start by Treating AI as â€œManual Labor + Recorderâ€â€

Let Claude handle:

  • Debugging

    • Help locate stack traces, explain errors, reproduce bugs
    • Write temporary scripts for validation

  • Tests, documentation, and comments

    • Auto-complete unit tests, generate mocks
    • Summarize PR changes, generate README and API docs

  • Frontend and visualization

    • Produce page scaffolds and style options
    • Build internal tools, dashboards, data visualizations

  • Small refactors and â€œpaper cutsâ€

    • Break a blob of code into functions
    • Rename variables, extract shared logic

For these, just write clearer acceptance criteria. Results will beat asking it to â€œthink up an architecture from scratch.â€

2) Design and Planning: Use AI as a Brainstorming Partner

Section titled â€œ2) Design and Planning: Use AI as a Brainstorming Partnerâ€

For high-level design, Claude works best when you:

  • Ask for multiple architecture options with pros/cons
  • Let it draft RFC/technical design first versions
  • Simulate reviews from different personas (e.g., â€œwhat would security ask?â€)

Decision-making, trade-offs, and final sign-off stay with you.

3) Infra/DevOps: Scripts and Docs Can Be Delegated, Production Commands Are Yours

Section titled â€œ3) Infra/DevOps: Scripts and Docs Can Be Delegated, Production Commands Are Yoursâ€

In Infra scenarios, it is safe to give AI:

  • Explanations of complex Kubernetes YAML or Terraform configs
  • CI/CD pipeline templates
  • Log reading and first-pass root-cause analysis

For commands or change plans that hit production, require:

  • A human to review again
  • A teammateâ€™s review
  • A dry run in staging when needed

Set a simple team rule:

â€œAny command that directly affects production must be edited and executed by a human.â€

4) Make Your Own â€œAI Task Mapâ€

Section titled â€œ4) Make Your Own â€œAI Task Mapâ€â€

Following Anthropic, you can draw a table for the team:

  • Rows: Debug / Frontend / New features / Tests / Docs / Refactoring / Design / Infra â€¦

  • Columns:

    • Does AI draft it?
    • Is AI allowed to finish it alone?
    • Who reviews the final output?

This becomes your â€œAI usage policy.â€ Update it quarterly; when models upgrade, move more tasks into the AI column.

VI. The Future Engineer: More Full Stack, With Stronger Judgment

Section titled â€œVI. The Future Engineer: More Full Stack, With Stronger Judgmentâ€

One survey insight resonated with me:

  • Employees estimated that 27% of Claude-assisted work would not exist without AIâ€”extra refactors, dashboards, internal tools.

So Claude is not just speeding up existing work; it makes you do valuable things you â€œnever had time for.â€

At the same time, many worry:

  • With less time writing code, will my hands get rusty?
  • Supervising AI needs experience, yet experience is being eaten by AI.

This is the â€œoversight paradoxâ€:

Using AI well requires strong judgment, and judgment itself needs hands-on practice.

A healthier approach might be:

  • Use AI boldly for high-ROI tasks.
  • Keep a portion of â€œhandwritten trainingâ€ for yourself.
  • Treat AI as an accelerator for your skill growth, not a substitute.

In the long run, what will engineers look like?

  • More like a mix of product + architecture + project manager + AI wrangler.
  • Focus more on â€œwhat to buildâ€ and â€œwhy,â€ rather than â€œexactly how this line of code looks.â€

Conclusion: Use AI in the Right Places and Become the Teamâ€™s â€œProductivity Arbitrageurâ€

Section titled â€œConclusion: Use AI in the Right Places and Become the Teamâ€™s â€œProductivity Arbitrageurâ€â€

Anthropicâ€™s internal survey points to a clear mindset:

  • Do not expect AI to 10x every task.
  • The real gap is whether you dare and know how to give it the right tasks.

If you are an engineer or tech lead, take a moment now to list your work:

  • Which tasks are easy to verify, repetitive and dull, and can be handed to Claude today?
  • Which tasks involve high-level design and team strategyâ€”let it act as â€œthink tank,â€ not â€œghostwriterâ€?

Draw that â€œAI task map,â€ and your productivity in the team is already a big step ahead.

item.title: From Frontend to Monitoring: A Practical Engineering Map for Agentic AI
item.content:encoded:
Introduction:

Section titled â€œIntroduction:â€

In the past two years, terms like â€œAgentic AIâ€ and â€œAI Agentâ€ have been overused to the point of clichÃ©.

When many people hear â€œAgent,â€ they immediately think:

â€œI can build one too; just use a large model + Prompt + LangChain and thatâ€™s it.â€

But when it comes to actual projects, they discover: A production-ready Agentic AI is far more than just a simple llm(prompt) call.

The â€œiceberg diagramâ€ you see today lays out a practical Agentic AI technology stack for everyone to see clearly: Visible above the water are the chat interfaces and Web Apps you see; Submerged below is a comprehensive system for document processing, vector databases, retrieval, monitoring, and deployment.

In this article, I want to take you through this â€œAgentic AI Icebergâ€ from top to bottom, using plain language as much as possible.

I. Above the Water: The â€œShellâ€ You See

Section titled â€œI. Above the Water: The â€œShellâ€ You Seeâ€

1. Frontend: You Think Itâ€™s an â€œInterface,â€ Itâ€™s Actually an â€œExperience Engineâ€

Section titled â€œ1. Frontend: You Think Itâ€™s an â€œInterface,â€ Itâ€™s Actually an â€œExperience Engineâ€â€

The diagram lists frontend frameworks like React, Next.js, and Streamlit, paired with hosting environments like Azure App Service.

Many AI projects start by just wrapping a dialog box around a model, which looks usable; But when it comes time for internal colleagues or clients to use it, problems arise:

  • Supporting multi-turn conversation history
  • Handling file uploads, result exports, and visualization
  • Implementing permission controls and organizational statistics

These all fall on the frontend + simple backend.

In short: The frontend isnâ€™t just â€œwriting some UI by the wayâ€; it is the â€œconsoleâ€ for your entire Agent experience. If you donâ€™t think this through, users will just think:

â€œIsnâ€™t this just ChatGPT with a skin?â€

II. The Middle of the Iceberg: The Knowledge Pipeline That Lets the Agent â€œRead the Worldâ€

Section titled â€œII. The Middle of the Iceberg: The Knowledge Pipeline That Lets the Agent â€œRead the Worldâ€â€

The real power of Agentic AI lies in â€œunderstanding your own dataâ€. This corresponds to these layers in the diagram: Document Ingestion â†’ Chunking/Preprocessing â†’ Vector Representation â†’ Vector Database â†’ Retrieval Layer.

1. Document Ingestion: Feeding the Agent Clean â€œRaw Materialsâ€

Section titled â€œ1. Document Ingestion: Feeding the Agent Clean â€œRaw Materialsâ€â€

Components like Microsoft Fabric, Azure AI OCR, Apache Tika, and LangChain do very plain work:

  • Uniformly extracting content from PDFs, Word docs, web pages, and screenshots
  • Removing noise, ads, and messy formatting
  • Structuring data, such as tables of contents, headings, paragraphs, and tables

Think of it this way:

To feed a bodybuilder, you must first ensure â€œreal meat and vegetables,â€ not junk food.

If you just throw a bunch of raw PDFs at the model and expect it to be your â€œenterprise search/knowledge assistant,â€ you are basically playing with fire.

2. Chunking & Preprocessing: Cutting Knowledge into Bite-Sized Pieces for the Model

Section titled â€œ2. Chunking & Preprocessing: Cutting Knowledge into Bite-Sized Pieces for the Modelâ€

Tools like spaCy, Hugging Face, LangChain, and some capabilities of Azure AI Search in the diagram are there to help you do this:

  • Intelligent chunking by paragraph or logical structure
  • Identifying entities and topics, doing some lightweight NLP preprocessing
  • Some also add metadata tags (e.g., source system, time, business line)

What happens if this step isnâ€™t done well?

  • Either the chunk is too large: super long context, expensive and inaccurate
  • Or the chunk is too fragmented: the model sees a pile of â€œdebrisâ€ each time, answering irrelevantly

A common engineering approach is to create a dynamic chunking strategy based on document structure + word count + semantics, paired with overlapping windows to ensure â€œno key information is missed in a queryâ€.

3. Embeddings: Compressing Enterprise Knowledge into â€œVector Fingerprintsâ€

Section titled â€œ3. Embeddings: Compressing Enterprise Knowledge into â€œVector Fingerprintsâ€â€

This is where Embedding models like Azure OpenAI, OpenAI, and Cohere come into play.

Simply put, they help you convert:

Text â†’ High-dimensional Vector

The distance between vectors represents â€œsemantic similarity.â€

Why is this step critical?

Because questions in an enterprise basically look like this:

  • â€œHelp me check the reasons for the abnormal return rate of a certain product in 2023?â€
  • â€œList the differences in contract terms between these versions?â€

No one searches by exact original text; everyone asks â€œrandomly in natural language,â€ and the Agent has to rely on semantic retrieval to quickly find the truly relevant content in your knowledge base.

4. Vector Database: A â€œGym-Specific Hard Driveâ€ for the Agent

Section titled â€œ4. Vector Database: A â€œGym-Specific Hard Driveâ€ for the Agentâ€

The diagram lists Azure AI Search, Cosmos DB, PostgreSQL + vector plugins, as well as Milvus, FAISS, etc.

In the real world, you basically have to consider a few things:

  • When the data volume is large, can retrieval still maintain millisecond-level response?
  • Does it support hybrid search (vector + keyword + filter conditions)?
  • How are security and isolation handled, such as sharding by tenant, department, or project?

Here you are actually choosing your â€œAgent Memory Hubâ€. Choose wrong, and all your subsequent â€œRAG + Agentâ€ capabilities will be stuck on performance and cost.

5. Retrieval Layer: Let the Agent â€œLook Up Before Thinkingâ€

Section titled â€œ5. Retrieval Layer: Let the Agent â€œLook Up Before Thinkingâ€â€

This layer is what everyone calls RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation):

  • LangChain, LlamaIndex, and Haystack do retrieval orchestration
  • Azure AI Search provides built-in retrieval + ranking capabilities

You can design a fixed routine for the Agent:

User asks â†’ Retrieve N pieces of related knowledge â†’ Let the large model answer based on â€œevidenceâ€ â†’ Return citations to the user when necessary

If this step is done well, the Agentâ€™s â€œhallucination rateâ€ and â€œnonsenseâ€ will drop by an order of magnitude.

III. Prompt Engineering Layer: From â€œWriting Promptsâ€ to â€œDesigning Strategiesâ€

Section titled â€œIII. Prompt Engineering Layer: From â€œWriting Promptsâ€ to â€œDesigning Strategiesâ€â€

The diagram includes Prompty, LangChain, and DSPy.

Many peopleâ€™s understanding of Prompts is stuck at â€œthinking of a few good English descriptions.â€

But Prompts in Agentic AI are closer to a type of:

â€œDecision Strategy + Workflow Orchestration Languageâ€

They can be roughly divided into categories:

  • System Prompts: Define role, tone, boundaries
  • Tool Invocation Strategy: When to check the knowledge base, when to call an API
  • Multi-Agent Collaboration: How the planning, execution, and review roles talk to each other

Tools like DSPy even try to â€œautomatically optimize Promptsâ€, somewhat like treating Prompts as â€œparameters,â€ tuning them through datasets and feedback signals.

Only when you start managing Prompts as â€œexperimental, iterative product configurationsâ€ rather than just scribbling them down, will the ceiling of large model applications be opened.

IV. LLM Layer: Not â€œChoosing a Model,â€ But â€œChoosing a Brain Comboâ€

Section titled â€œIV. LLM Layer: Not â€œChoosing a Model,â€ But â€œChoosing a Brain Comboâ€â€

The diagram mentions Azure OpenAI, plus models like LLaMA and Mistral.

In real projects, using a single model for everything is no longer very realistic; more often, itâ€™s about making a â€œmodel platterâ€:

  • Cheap models run most chitchat and simple tasks
  • Specialized models run vertical tasks like code, law, medicine
  • Enterprises will also mix open-source models + commercial models to balance privacy and cost

You can understand this layer as:

The Agentâ€™s â€œMulti-Core Brain Poolâ€

It has to be responsible for those â€œPrompt strategiesâ€ and â€œretrieval resultsâ€ above, making decisions that are as reliable and consistent with business logic as possible.

V. Monitoring & Evaluation: If an Agent Isnâ€™t Monitored, It Slowly Becomes a â€œTime Bombâ€

Section titled â€œV. Monitoring & Evaluation: If an Agent Isnâ€™t Monitored, It Slowly Becomes a â€œTime Bombâ€â€

The diagram shows Azure Foundry, OpenTelemetry, and Grafana.

A pitfall many teams fall into is:

â€œThe app is online, people can use it, so itâ€™s a success.â€

A few weeks later youâ€™ll find:

  • Users often complain â€œthe answer this time is different from the last timeâ€
  • After a model upgrade, results in some scenarios get worse, but no one notices
  • Certain Prompts are called tens of thousands of times a day, costs blowing straight through the budget

At this point, Observability and Evaluation become critical:

  • Record the input, output, tools used, latency, and cost of every call
  • Establish an automatic evaluation set for key scenarios, running comparisons as soon as a new version comes
  • Hang these metrics on a dashboard like Grafana for operations and tech to monitor together

In short:

An Agent without monitoring is like a car without rearview mirrors. The faster you drive, the more dangerous it is.

VI. Infrastructure & Deployment: Turning the Agent from a â€œLab Toyâ€ into a â€œProductivity Toolâ€

Section titled â€œVI. Infrastructure & Deployment: Turning the Agent from a â€œLab Toyâ€ into a â€œProductivity Toolâ€â€

The bottom layer contains things like Azure Container Apps, AKS, Docker, and Kubernetes.

The problem they solve is really just two words: Stability.

  • Withstanding high concurrency
  • Meeting high availability requirements (canâ€™t keep crashing)
  • Supporting multiple environments (dev, test, staging, prod)

Many people think everything is fine when doing a Demo: â€œIt runs pretty fast locally.â€

But in a production environment, you have to consider:

  • How to do horizontal scaling and auto-scaling?
  • How to split model services and business services?
  • How to isolate and audit sensitive data?

These things are the engineering details at the very bottom of the iceberg. The sooner you realize their existence, the less rework youâ€™ll have later.

VII. A Landing Route Suggestion for You Who Want to Build Agentic AI

Section titled â€œVII. A Landing Route Suggestion for You Who Want to Build Agentic AIâ€

If you are currently in a company and planning to build an â€œIntelligent Customer Service,â€ â€œInternal Knowledge Assistant,â€ or â€œAI Operations Assistant,â€ you can think about the route like this:

  1. Start with a clear scenario For example, â€œallow operations to instantly query any historical campaign data,â€ rather than â€œmake an Agent that can chat about anything.â€

  2. Run a MVP with the simplest frontend + RAG pipeline Donâ€™t use complex multi-Agent scheduling at the start. Being able to do: â€œAsk business question â†’ Check knowledge base â†’ Provide cited answerâ€ is already very powerful.

  3. Leave hooks for monitoring and evaluation from the very beginning Even if you only do simple logging + a few typical question sets at first, it will save a lot of time for tuning later.

  4. Treat this iceberg diagram as a â€œTechnical Debt Listâ€ Think clearly:

    • Which layers must be done now
    • Which layers can be added gradually later
    • Which layers can use cloud vendor/open-source solutions to â€œborrow for a whileâ€

Wait until you make the first version of the Agent indispensable to the teamâ€™s daily routine, then slowly dig down into this iceberg, and you will find:

The truly hard part is not â€œknowing how to use large models,â€ but â€œbeing able to embed large models into business, running stably, for a long time, and affordably.â€

Conclusion: Agentic AI Is Not a New Term, But a Whole New Engineering Paradigm

Section titled â€œConclusion: Agentic AI Is Not a New Term, But a Whole New Engineering Paradigmâ€

Back to that diagram.

Above the water are the â€œcool AI applicationsâ€ users see; Below the water is a comprehensive engineering system from data and models to monitoring and deployment.

If you are currently a developer, product manager, or are considering using AI to improve business efficiency, I highly recommend saving this â€œAgentic AI Iceberg Diagramâ€ as a long-term reference engineering map.

Next time you are urged to make â€œan AI Agent Demo,â€ you can throw this diagram at them and say with a smile:

â€œWe can first make the part visible above the water, but to run in production, the whole iceberg below will have to be filled in sooner or later.â€

What do you think, in your current work/project, which layer of this iceberg is the hardest? Welcome to chat in the comments section about the most â€œoutrageousâ€ AI project requirements you have encountered.

item.title: Johari Window Model and Four-Quadrant Analysis of Humanâ€“AI Dialogue
item.content:encoded:
Introduction to the Johari Window Model and Its Four Quadrants

Section titled â€œIntroduction to the Johari Window Model and Its Four Quadrantsâ€

The Johari Window is a psychological model for improving self-awareness and interpersonal communication, proposed by psychologists Joseph Luft and Harrington Ingham in 1955. It divides personal cognition into four quadrants (or four â€œwindowsâ€):

  • Open Area (å¼€æ”¾åŒº): Information known to both yourself and othersâ€”public behaviors, attitudes, and traits. This is the â€œyou know, I knowâ€ domain.

  • Blind Area (ç›²åŒº): Information others can see but you overlook, such as behavioral traits apparent to others that you yourself donâ€™t notice. This corresponds to â€œyou know, I donâ€™tâ€, i.e., your cognitive blind spots.

  • Hidden Area (éšè—åŒº): Private information you know but others do not, like personal privacy or inner thoughts. This is the â€œyou donâ€™t know, I knowâ€ domain, also called the privacy zone.

  • Unknown Area (æœªçŸ¥åŒº): Potential information or traits unknown to both you and others, including untapped potential. This corresponds to the â€œyou donâ€™t know, I donâ€™tâ€ fully unknown domain.

The core idea is to expand the open area, reduce the blind and hidden areas, and explore the unknown area to enhance self-awareness and communication.

Mapping the Four Quadrants to Humanâ€“AI Dialogue

Section titled â€œMapping the Four Quadrants to Humanâ€“AI Dialogueâ€

When mapping the Johari Window to humanâ€“AI dialogue, we can treat â€œselfâ€ as the human user and â€œotherâ€ as the AI system. The axes of â€œknowing/not knowingâ€ become â€œwhether the human knowsâ€ and â€œwhether the AI knows.â€ The Johari quadrants are redefined in this context to frame humanâ€“machine conversations. The schematic below illustrates the correspondence:

A quadrant diagram of the Johari Window applied to humanâ€“AI dialogue. The horizontal axis indicates whether the AI has the information (right = AI knows), and the vertical axis indicates whether the human has the information (top = human doesnâ€™t). Each quadrant reflects a different humanâ€“machine cognition setup: both know (open area), AI knows but the human doesnâ€™t (blind area), the human knows but AI doesnâ€™t (hidden area), and neither knows (unknown area).

Specifically, the four quadrants in humanâ€“AI dialogue mean:

  • Open Area (human knows + AI knows): Information or context is transparent to both parties. Both share the same knowledge base and clear task premisesâ€”akin to a public knowledge domain.

  • Blind Area (human doesnâ€™t know + AI knows): The AI holds information the user lacks. The userâ€™s question is their blind spot, but the AI may have relevant knowledge or skills to provide an answer the user doesnâ€™t know.

  • Hidden Area (human knows + AI doesnâ€™t): The user holds information the AI lacks, such as personal background, private data, or specialized knowledge. If not provided, the AI operates with missing context.

  • Unknown Area (human doesnâ€™t know + AI doesnâ€™t): A new problem domain where neither side has ready answersâ€”innovative exploration where both must discover together.

These quadrants reframe humanâ€“AI knowledge relationships. With this lens, we can tailor questioning styles and interaction strategies to make dialogue more efficient and intelligent.

Dialogue Strategy Analysis for the Four Quadrants

Section titled â€œDialogue Strategy Analysis for the Four Quadrantsâ€

For each quadrant, we examine suitable question types, prompting and response strategies, and the AIâ€™s limitations. Different quadrants imply different knowledge relationships and call for adjusted dialogue tactics.

Open Area: Knowledge Is Transparent to Both Sides

Section titled â€œOpen Area: Knowledge Is Transparent to Both Sidesâ€

The open area is â€œthe human knows, the AI knows,â€ where both share context. Examples include having AI polish user-written text, translate a sentence, or answer a well-scoped question. Here the AI can act as a â€œhigh-efficiency assistant.â€

Suitable question types: Tasks with clear context and shared backgroundâ€”text polishing, translation, format conversion, simple Q&A, and other routine tasks. Human and AI understand the requirements consistently, so communication costs are lowest.

Human prompting: State the task and requirements directly and clearly. Provide explicit instructionsâ€”task, desired format, and constraints. Example: â€œSummarize the key points of the following text concisely.â€ Excess background is unnecessary because the AI already â€œknowsâ€ the relevant knowledge; over-explaining may even distract.

AI response strategy: In the open area, AI is the executor: follow instructions and complete the task efficiently. With clear context, the AI can rely on its trained knowledge or skills to answer, typically with high accuracy and speed.

AI limitations: Performance is usually strong here. The risk is user over-description confusing the AI or producing verbosity (the AI tries to process redundant guidance). Conversely, if instructions are vague, even shared knowledge wonâ€™t ensure the AI grasps intent. The main challenge is clarity of requests, not knowledge gaps.

Blind Area: AI Knows What Humans Donâ€™t

Section titled â€œBlind Area: AI Knows What Humans Donâ€™tâ€

The blind area is â€œthe human doesnâ€™t know, the AI knows.â€ The user seeks knowledge or answers they lackâ€”asking for concepts, data, or insight. The AI acts as an â€œaccelerated learnerâ€ or knowledge provider.

Recommended question types: Knowledge and explanatory questionsâ€”definitions of terms, concept explainers, industry status analyses, etc. These target user blind spots, and the AI often covers them in its training data, filling knowledge gaps.

Human prompting tips: Good questioning and gradual probing are key. Since the user is unfamiliar, one query may not cover all they need. Break big questions into sub-questions and go layer by layer: start with definitions, then principles, examples, and applications. For instance: â€œFirst, what is the concept? What problem does it solve? What core principles? Can you give examples?â€ Iterative dialogue helps fully surface what the AI knows.

AI response strategy: Answer in detail and sequence to help the user grasp unknown contentâ€”provide definitions, principles, examples, and extensions. Ideally, the AI responds in a teaching cadence, like a tutor guiding step by step. But it should avoid dumping too much at once and match the userâ€™s pacing.

AI limitations: The challenge is the user â€œnot knowing what they donâ€™t know.â€ Vague questions can lead to unfocused or generic answers. Studies show very simple queries can make it hard for AI to infer needs, yielding broad responsesâ€”sometimes worse than traditional search. If training data are limited or biased, AI may give inaccurate answers the user canâ€™t detect. Thus in the blind area, humans should ask from multiple angles and cross-check sources, while AI should admit uncertainty or cite sources to build trust.

Hidden Area: Humans Know What AI Doesnâ€™t

Section titled â€œHidden Area: Humans Know What AI Doesnâ€™tâ€

The hidden area is â€œthe human has it, the AI doesnâ€™tâ€â€”personal experience, private data, or contextual background. The AI is a blank slate here and needs the user to feed the necessary information before it can work. The AI is a â€œnewcomerâ€ or â€œguided learner,â€ and the human is the expert supplying knowledge.

Typical dialogue scenarios: Customized and personalized tasksâ€”summarizing an internal report, analyzing user-provided data, etc. The required information isnâ€™t in the AIâ€™s training set because itâ€™s unique to the user, so it must be supplied. Example: â€œHereâ€™s our companyâ€™s sales dataâ€”analyze performance.â€

Human prompting: In the hidden area, first provide sufficient background, then ask the questionâ€”â€œfeed first, then ask.â€ Make the information structured and clear: background, key data, terminology, and the task you expect the AI to perform. For example, paste a piece of proprietary material (product docs, meeting notes), then ask: â€œSummarize the main conclusions above and give recommendations.â€ If you just say â€œWe have a new project X, please analyze,â€ without details, the AI lacks the basics to respond effectively. Donâ€™t skimp on explaining what the AI doesnâ€™t know.

AI response strategy: Once it receives user-provided information, the AI should make full use of itâ€”combine the new content with its commonsense knowledge to summarize, analyze, or create. Given an internal report, it can extract key points and summarize or answer questions based on the provided facts. Here the AI is a â€œknowledge integratorâ€ and â€œlearner.â€ When needed, it should also ask clarifying questions to ensure it understands the supplied materials correctly.

AI limitations: In the hidden area, â€œno flour, no breadâ€â€”without user-provided proprietary info, the AI canâ€™t solve customized problems. Even with data, it may misread complex professional nuances or struggle to integrate new information due to model limitsâ€”misinterpreting data meaning or missing critical context. Users should supervise answers to ensure the AI used the provided info correctly. To reduce hidden-area drawbacks, techniques like retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) let AIs query external knowledge bases during dialogue. With such methods, future AIs can better ingest user-domain knowledge and improve responses.

Unknown Area: Neither Side Knows

Section titled â€œUnknown Area: Neither Side Knowsâ€

The unknown area is â€œthe human doesnâ€™t know, the AI doesnâ€™t know.â€ This is open-ended creative dialogue or frontier explorationâ€”no standard answer, so both brainstorm together. AI and human start from the same line, with AI as a â€œco-creator.â€

Suitable question types: Open creativity, strategy planning, frontier research hypotheses. Examples: brainstorming business models, sci-fi ideas, or undecided scientific questions. Thereâ€™s no right or wrongâ€”focus on broad exploration and innovation.

Human prompting: Use open-ended prompts that grant creative freedom while adding constraints to keep outputs meaningful. Pose hypotheticals like: â€œIf we were to build a city on Mars, what innovations would we need?â€ and ask for multi-angle plans. Or request divergent thinkingâ€”â€œGive 10 possible solutions,â€ then the human filters feasibility. In the unknown area, the human is the guide and evaluator: steer the AI and keep probing or adjusting based on answers.

AI response strategy: With no fixed answer, the AI should be creative and provide varied perspectives or ideas. It must also take human feedback to converge on better options. The AI can start with freewheeling ideas; the human flags whatâ€™s valuable or unrealistic; then the AI deepens or shifts direction accordingly. In this quadrant, itâ€™s â€œcollaborative explorationâ€: AI supplies ideas, humans evaluate and synthesize, iterating to approach solutions.

AI limitations: The AI lacks real-world validation. Its ideas stem from corpus-based analogy and recombinationâ€”sometimes novel, sometimes impractical. Without grasping physical causality or business viability, AI creativity needs human vetting. On unknown questions, AI may fabricate plausible-sounding explanations (â€œhallucinationsâ€) without basis. Humans must spot and question unreliable parts. In the unknown area, AI sparks inspiration, but humans make the judgments. Human intuition, emotion, and values remain irreplaceableâ€”especially with unknowns.

Human View: Designing Effective Questions for High-Quality Responses

Section titled â€œHuman View: Designing Effective Questions for High-Quality Responsesâ€

From the questionerâ€™s perspective, the Johari Window can greatly improve dialogue quality with AI. The key is knowing what you and the AI each know, and tailoring questions accordingly. Suggestions:

Identify the quadrant: Before asking, decide which quadrant the issue falls into. If both know (open), give clear instructions. If you donâ€™t but AI might (blind), ask step by step. If AI needs your proprietary info (hidden), provide context first. If itâ€™s open exploration (unknown), ask open questions and encourage multi-angle answers. Conscious quadrant mapping helps pick the right prompting style and avoids one-size-fits-all questions that underperform.

Provide sufficient, necessary context: Information fuels good answers. Context strategy differs by quadrant: in the open area, offer concise task requirementsâ€”donâ€™t overload; in the hidden area, give the missing background so AI has material to work with. Think from the AIâ€™s view: â€œWhat does it need to answer accurately?â€ Provide that proactively instead of making it guess.

Use iterative dialogue: You donâ€™t need a one-shot, all-encompassing question. Gradual deepening often works better. In the blind area, break down complex questions; in the unknown area, have AI generate ideas first, then follow up for elaboration. Continuous dialogue guides the AI toward your needs and lets you correct misunderstandings.

Specify expectations and format: Explicitly state how you want the AI to respondâ€”length, format, style. This boosts quality: â€œAnswer within 100 words,â€ â€œlist bullet points,â€ etc. In the open area, it keeps answers concise; in the blind area, it prevents sprawling explanations.

Keep feedback and guidance flowing: Dialogue is two-way. Based on initial answers, decide the next question. This matters most in the unknown and blind areas. If the AI misses the mark, point it out and request fixes: â€œYou omitted Xâ€”please add detail.â€ Feedback guides the AI toward the target output and lets you steer its understanding.

In short, ask with intent, not at random. As Einstein said, â€œThe important thing is to not stop questioning.â€ In the AI era, crafting good questions is central to collaboration. Master the art, and even with ever-smarter AI, we can steer the dialogue and get better answersâ€”the skilled questioner wonâ€™t be replaced.

AI System View: Understanding Human Needs and Improving Blind Spots

Section titled â€œAI System View: Understanding Human Needs and Improving Blind Spotsâ€

From the AI system side, serving humans better means continually improving understanding of human needs, intent, and its own blind spots. Using the Johari lens, potential improvements include:

Improve acquisition and understanding of user context: Todayâ€™s large models canâ€™t directly know user-hidden info, but tech can shrink the â€œhidden area.â€ For instance, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) lets AI query a user knowledge base or live data during dialogue. When questions touch private domains, the AI can fetch relevant materials to grasp human context. In practice, AI should support user uploads and remember dialogue context to build a user-specific knowledge picture. With privacy protected, richer background reduces miscommunication from information asymmetry.

Learn to ask clarifying questions: Humans sometimes ask ambiguously or embed hidden premisesâ€”AIâ€™s â€œhuman blind spot.â€ Ideally, AI detects ambiguity or missing pieces and asks for clarification instead of charging ahead with potentially off-target answers. If a user says â€œSummarize the report,â€ AI can reply: â€œWhich report? What aspects should I focus on?â€ Emulating human clarifying behavior helps AI capture intent, reducing misaligned answers and improving efficiency.

Surface its own knowledge limits: In the blind and unknown areas, when AI senses the question exceeds its knowledge or carries high uncertainty, it should be frank. It might say, â€œI donâ€™t have enough information on this latest studyâ€”should I search for recent sources?â€ or offer a search mode. This prevents confidently wrong answers that make users think AI is â€œall-knowing.â€ Admitting limits and seeking cooperation (extra info or retrieval) can actually raise quality and trust.

Learn from feedback to shrink blind spots: Every dialogue is a chance to learn human needs and blind spots. AI should learn from user feedback and corrections: repeated prompt tweaks or dissatisfaction suggest misunderstandingsâ€”maybe about a termâ€™s meaning or what users care about. Future AIs could dynamically adjust reasoning, switching knowledge modules to get closer to user expectations. Interactive learning helps adapt to personal prompting styles and bridge the gap between general models and individualized needs.

Expand knowledge boundaries and update models: AIâ€™s â€œknownsâ€ shift over time. New knowledge emerges constantly; todayâ€™s unknown becomes tomorrowâ€™s blind or open area. Plugins and retrieval already try to expand AIâ€™s knowledge. Developers should update models regularly with the latest public knowledge, pushing the AI-knowledge axis rightward. Reinforcement learning can help preserve high-quality user interactions. This gradually shrinks AI blind spots and raises expertise across domains. Still, human intuition, emotion, and values remain hard to replace. AI should be designed to understand and respect theseâ€”showing empathy and caution on ethical or emotional topics.

In sum, on the AI side, the path is to better gather and use human-provided information, handle ambiguous prompts more intelligently, and be humbler about its limits. That brings dialogue closer to true partnership: AI better understands human intent and context, and humans trust AI responses more. Thatâ€™s the goal of humanâ€“machine symbiosisâ€”shrinking panes of misunderstanding, expanding shared knowledge, and achieving co-creation rather than mere tool-use. With the Johari lens on humanâ€“machine exchanges, every conversation becomes not just answer-seeking but a journey of mutual cognitive inspiration.

item.title: December to January: The Big Events US Stock Investors Must Track
item.content:encoded:
As December begins, the US stock market enters its most â€œbewitchingâ€ stretch of the year: on one side is the historically high-probability â€œSanta Claus rally,â€ on the other a stack of landmines packed into just over a monthâ€”rate decisions, inflation prints, AI bellwether earnings, expectations for a yen rate hike, and US fiscal and Federal Reserve personnel moves.

Background Overview

Section titled â€œBackground Overviewâ€

In November, US stocks rode a roller coaster of â€œkill sentiment first, then pull expectationsâ€:

  • In the first half, AI bubble worries plus cooling rate-cut expectations â†’ tech stocks plunged
  • In the second half, the government shutdown ended + rate-cut expectations warmed up again â†’ the three major indices rebounded together

From this December through next January, several key dates will collectively determine:

  • Whether the Fed starts a new rate-cut cycle
  • Whether AI investment is real money instead of a slide-deck story
  • Whether global liquidity quietly shifts from â€œsuper looseâ€ to â€œslightly tighterâ€
  • Whether US fiscal and political dynamics stay in tug-of-war or slip back into disorder

I. Key Timeline (Decemberâ€“January)

Section titled â€œI. Key Timeline (Decemberâ€“January)â€

Times are in Beijing time so you can drop them straight into your calendar.

1. Central Banks & Rate Path

Section titled â€œ1. Central Banks & Rate Pathâ€

December 1: Fed officially ends QT (balance-sheet reduction)

  • Based on the October 28â€“29 FOMC decision, the balance sheet stops shrinking as of December 1; QT2 formally concludes

December 9â€“10: Fed December meeting

  • December 10, 14:00 ET (December 11, 03:00 Beijing) policy statement and rate decision
  • December 10, 14:30 ET, Powell press conference
  • Market consensus: >80% probability of another 25 bp cut

December 18â€“19: Bank of Japan meeting

  • On December 1 in Nagoya, Ueda explicitly said the pros and cons of a rate hike will be discussed at the December meeting
  • He mentioned explaining the path once rates reach 0.75%, one of the most hawkish signals so far

December 30, 03:00 (31st): Fed December minutes

  • Fed calendar shows the minutes of the December 9â€“10 meeting will be released December 30, 14:00 ET (Beijing December 31, 03:00)

December: Trump may nominate the next Fed Chair

  • Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has repeatedly hinted a nomination is very likely before Christmas
  • Kevin Hassett, head of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, is widely seen as the frontrunner

2. Major Macro Data: Jobs + Inflation

Section titled â€œ2. Major Macro Data: Jobs + Inflationâ€

Because the US government shut down in Octoberâ€“November, some economic data releases were halted; every data point now carries a â€œmake-up homeworkâ€ feel.

December 16, 21:30: US November nonfarm payrolls

  • Per the BLS calendar: November jobs report at 8:30 ET on December 16 (21:30 Beijing)

December 18, 21:30: US November CPI

  • Because of the shutdown delay to October CPI, the November CPI release was pushed to December 18

January 9, 21:30: December nonfarm

  • BLS plans to release December employment data on January 9, 2026

January 13, 21:30: December CPI

  • December CPI is set for January 13, 2026, the first â€œtone-setterâ€ for the 2026 inflation path

3. AI Supply Chain Earnings

Section titled â€œ3. AI Supply Chain Earningsâ€

December 12 pre-dawn: Broadcom (AVGO) Q4 earnings

  • AVGO will report FY2025 Q4 and full-year results after market close on December 11 (early December 12 Beijing) and host a call

December 18 pre-dawn: Micron (MU) Q1 earnings

  • MU will report FY2026 Q1 after market close on December 17 (early December 18 Beijing)

These two firmsâ€”one a â€œfull-stack + networking + ASICâ€ powerhouse in AI servers/accelerator ecosystems, the other a key supplier of memory/HBMâ€”are front-line sentinels for whether â€œAI infrastructure demand is real or a bubble.â€

4. Fiscal & Politics: Shutdown Aftermath & Fed Personnel

Section titled â€œ4. Fiscal & Politics: Shutdown Aftermath & Fed Personnelâ€

Government just reopened: stopgap funding to January 30, 2026

  • From October 1, 2025, the US federal government shut down for 40+ days
  • In mid-November, Congress passed a continuing resolution to keep the government funded until January 30, 2026
  • Meanwhile, the extension of ACA subsidies from the Obama era was pushed to mid-December for another vote

These fiscal tussles both affect the FY2026 deficit and Treasury issuance cadence, and add political pressure on the Fed.

II. Monetary Policy: Fed + BOJ

Section titled â€œII. Monetary Policy: Fed + BOJâ€

1. Fed: From â€œhike + shrinkâ€ to â€œcut + end shrinkâ€

Section titled â€œ1. Fed: From â€œhike + shrinkâ€ to â€œcut + end shrinkâ€â€

At the October meeting, the Fed already:

  • Lowered the fed funds rate 25 bp to 3.75%â€“4.00%
  • Announced QT2 would stop as of December 1, halting further balance-sheet runoff

Put simply: â€œrates move down, balance sheet stops decliningâ€â€”policy shifts from tight to â€œmildly loose.â€

But internally there is no unanimity; the October minutes showed clear divisions over further cuts, and Powell stressed that â€œwhether to cut again in December is not a done deal.â€

What to watch at the December 9â€“10 meeting?

  • Whether the dot plot and forward guidance spell out how many more cuts in 2026
  • Whether the language is â€œcut once, then observeâ€ or signals entry into a sustained cutting cycle
  • How they assess the impact of the shutdown data gap (many official October data points were missing)

Markets have already priced in â€œone more cut in Decemberâ€â€”banks from JP Morgan to BofA are betting on it.

If the outcome is â€œholdâ€ or a more hawkish message, it would be a notable hit to high-valuation names, especially high-beta AI stocks.

2. Fed Personnel: Who succeeds Powell?

Section titled â€œ2. Fed Personnel: Who succeeds Powell?â€

Powellâ€™s term expires May 2026. Trump has said multiple times, â€œI know who to pick,â€ but wonâ€™t replace him early.

Current storyline:

  • Treasury Secretary Bessent is leading the search, narrowing the list to five
  • Kevin Hassett, White House economic adviser, is the clear frontrunner in reports and betting markets
  • Bessent has hinted the name may drop before Christmas

Market takeaway is simple:

If the pick is more â€œpolitical and openly pro-rapid cuts,â€ the Fedâ€™s perceived independence post-2026 would be discounted, adding risk premia to the dollar and long-term inflation expectations.

In other words, this is not about a few days of trading; it sets the rules for the coming years.

3. BOJ: Yen hikes as an â€œinvisible kill shotâ€ to US stocks

Section titled â€œ3. BOJ: Yen hikes as an â€œinvisible kill shotâ€ to US stocksâ€

On December 1, Ueda delivered a rare hawkish signal in Nagoya:

  • Explicitly said a hike will be discussed at the December meeting
  • Stressed that once the rate is raised to 0.75%, the path will be detailed
  • Also noted that even with a hike, Japanâ€™s overall financial stance remains accommodative

Markets reacted immediately:

  • Yen strengthened quickly against the dollar
  • Japanese short-end yields hit multi-year highs
  • Global bond yields rose in tandem; US stocks pulled back that day

Why does this matter for US equity investors?

  • In recent years, plenty of global capital used cheap yen carry: borrow yen â†’ buy Treasuries, buy US stocks, especially high-valuation tech
  • If yen rates keep rising and the currency stabilizes or rebounds, that â€œcheap moneyâ€ pipeline gradually tightens
  • For growth stocks hypersensitive to rates and reliant on valuation expansion (AI names especially), this is a structural headwind

III. Data: Cooling Jobs + Easing Inflation

Section titled â€œIII. Data: Cooling Jobs + Easing Inflationâ€

The prevailing market narrative is: â€œSlowing growth + weaker jobs + easing inflation â†’ the Fed can safely cut more.â€

We need to stay sober about the data itself.

1. Jobs: Official data catching up to reality

Section titled â€œ1. Jobs: Official data catching up to realityâ€
  • Private datasets have for months flagged rising layoffs, more WARN notices, and tougher job searches
  • Consumer confidence slumped sharply in November, with the shutdown seen as a key drag
  • But because October data was halted by the shutdown, official Labor Department/BLS releases are only now getting back on track

December 16 (November nonfarm) and January 9 (December nonfarm):

If nonfarm adds and wage growth weaken noticeably:

  • Markets will feel firmer about â€œanother 2â€“3 cuts in 2026â€
  • Bullish for long-end Treasury yields, short-term positive for growth/tech

If the data stay firm:

  • It will deepen FOMC divisions over further cuts
  • Bearish for assets already priced for a dovish path (high-leverage REITs, high-valuation tech)

2. Inflation: November CPI is the â€œfirst real testâ€ post-shutdown

Section titled â€œ2. Inflation: November CPI is the â€œfirst real testâ€ post-shutdownâ€

Because of the shutdown, October CPI was delayed; November CPI was pushed to December 18.

This CPI print matters for two reasons:

  • Itâ€™s the first full inflation read after the government reopened
  • Awkward timingâ€”after the December 10 FOMCâ€”meaning the Fed meets with an â€œincompleteâ€ dataset

Markets expect November CPI YoY around 2.9%, with core a bit higher but still in a â€œnear-targetâ€ range.

If November and December CPI both land in the 2%â€“3% band, the Fed will have stronger â€œpolitical + dataâ€ cover to keep cutting slowly in 2026.

IV. AI Track: Two Scorecards from Broadcom & Micron

Section titled â€œIV. AI Track: Two Scorecards from Broadcom & Micronâ€

Over the past year, a handful of AI leaders captured most of the marketâ€™s gains. Year to date 2025, Alphabet and NVIDIA alone contributed roughly one-third of the S&P 500â€™s rise.

The violent swings in November largely asked: â€œCan AI investment returns justify current prices?â€

In that context, the two December earnings reports are especially critical:

1. After hours December 11: Broadcom (AVGO)

Section titled â€œ1. After hours December 11: Broadcom (AVGO)â€

Watch three areas:

AI revenue mix and growth

  • Goldman and other banks expect Broadcom to raise FY2026 AI revenue guidance again
  • Some forecasts see YoY growth potentially topping 100%

Capex cadence of major customers (hyperscalers/lab clients)

  • Alphabetâ€™s self-developed TPU is deeply tied to Broadcomâ€™s manufacturing and ecosystem
  • If clients slow AI capex, Broadcom canâ€™t escape the impact

Whether traditional businesses (handsets, broadband, enterprise networking) are being crowded out by AI

  • If legacy lines are pressured while AI surges, markets may treat Broadcom as â€œpure AI betaâ€
  • The opposite would frame it more as a â€œdefensive AI beneficiaryâ€

2. After hours December 17: Micron (MU)

Section titled â€œ2. After hours December 17: Micron (MU)â€

Micron is the temperature gauge on memory + HBM supply:

  • Pricing and production for HBM and high-end DRAM map directly to real AI server demand
  • If guidance shows data center demand still strong while PC/handset inventories clear, the story that â€œAI is pulling up the entire semi cycleâ€ holds better
  • Conversely, if management stresses customers trimming inventory and pulling less than expected, markets would cut 2026 AI capex forecasts a second time

V. Fiscal & Politics: The Shutdown Was Just a Trailer

Section titled â€œV. Fiscal & Politics: The Shutdown Was Just a Trailerâ€

From October 1 to November 12, 2025, the US endured one of its longest shutdownsâ€”40+ days:

  • The Census Bureau and BLS paused many data releases
  • Consumer confidence dropped sharply; retail sales weakened visibly
  • The White House economic team estimated direct costs of roughly $15 billion per week

The mid-November continuing resolution merely kicked the can to January 30, 2026:

  • Before then, Congress must agree on a full FY2026 budget and healthcare subsidy issues
  • Otherwise, either another shutdown or more short-term CRs

For markets, this means:

Uncertain Treasury supply + large deficit

  • Keeps upward pressure on long-end Treasury yields

Higher political risk premia

  • Especially if the next Fed Chair pick is clearly â€œaligned with White House wishesâ€
  • Layer on large tax cuts or new spending and markets will reprice the landscape

VI. â€œSanta Claus Rallyâ€: Does It Still Work This Year?

Section titled â€œVI. â€œSanta Claus Rallyâ€: Does It Still Work This Year?â€

Wall Street calls the tendency for US stocks to rise during the last five trading days of the year plus the first two of the new year these seven days the â€œSanta Claus rally.â€

Historical stats:

  • Since 1950, the S&P 500 has averaged ~1.3% gain over those seven days
  • Win rate close to 80%

Two caveats:

This is just a statistical pattern, not a law; 2024â€“2025 even saw a â€œreverse Santa Claus rally.â€

This year is unusual:

  • AI bubble debate is fierce
  • The Fed just ended QT
  • Japan may hike; the US is debating how many more cuts

A more realistic view:

If we still get a small Santa-plus-New-Year bounce, treat it as â€œa sentiment reset thanks to rate-cut expectations and easier liquidity.â€

But it cannot hide longer-term questions:

  • Whether AI valuations are reasonable
  • Whether jobs are clearly weakening
  • Whether fiscal policy is sustainable

VII. How Can Individual Investors Use This â€œEvent Calendarâ€?

Section titled â€œVII. How Can Individual Investors Use This â€œEvent Calendarâ€?â€

Here is a practical playbook:

1. Bake the dates into your position rules

Section titled â€œ1. Bake the dates into your position rulesâ€

Around December 9â€“10 FOMC

  • Dial back high-leverage, short-term, all-in options bets
  • Keep the portfolio positioned to absorb two-way swings on meeting night

December 11â€“18 (AVGO / MU earnings + nonfarm + CPI)

  • Differentiate pure AI beta (all story, little cash flow) from companies with solid profits
  • Consider using indices/ETFs to hedge some single-stock risk

Late Decemberâ€“mid-January (Santa rally + new nonfarm/CPI round)

  • If the market surges over the holidays, trim overall portfolio valuation (e.g., shift from 100% tech to 60% tech + 40% defensive/value)
  • If the Santa rally is absent or even plunges, treat it seriously as an early warning for 2026 risk assets

2. Watch rates, not just the index

Section titled â€œ2. Watch rates, not just the indexâ€

During this stretch, moves in the Treasury curve matter more than index levels:

  • Short end (2-year) â†’ captures expectations for the next 1â€“2 years of cuts
  • Long end (10-year) â†’ reflects worries about long-term inflation + fiscal sustainability

If post-December we see â€œshort end dives, long end rises,â€ that looks more like a â€œrecession worry + fiscal riskâ€ combo, not a clean equity-friendly rate-cut cycle.

3. Break the â€œstoryâ€ into â€œcash flows + discount rateâ€

Section titled â€œ3. Break the â€œstoryâ€ into â€œcash flows + discount rateâ€â€

Over the next month-plus, weâ€™re watching three dramas at once:

  • Fed: the discount-rate script
  • AI bellwether earnings: the cash-flow script
  • Fiscal and politics: the risk-premium script

Only when these three roughly line up can a â€œSanta Claus rallyâ€ morph into â€œthe start of a truly sustainable bull market.â€

Section titled â€œI. Overview of Core Events and Market Impactâ€

In November 2025, the US stock market faces a complex situation interwoven with five major categories of critical events, which will profoundly impact market direction. Based on current data analysis, the market is in a delicate balance of high valuations, low volatility, and high uncertainty.

  • The Supreme Courtâ€™s Tariff Ruling (November 5) is the biggest uncertainty factor this month. The Supreme Court will hold oral arguments on November 5, with a final ruling expected in late 2025 or early 2026. This ruling involves a risk of nearly $200 billion in tariff refunds. If the Supreme Court overturns the tariffs, the market may see significant positive news; if it supports the government, it implies continued trade uncertainty.
  • Sino-US trade relations saw a brief dÃ©tente at the end of October. After meeting in Korea, a one-year truce agreement was reached: the US will reduce tariffs on Chinese goods from 57% to 47% (fentanyl-related tariffs from 20% to 10%), and China will suspend rare earth export restrictions for one year. However, this is merely a tactical truce, not a structural solution. Both sides retain the option to restart the trade war, and the risk of escalation in November should be watched.
  • The government shutdown has lasted 29 days (as of October 31), making it one of the longest in US history. The Congressional Budget Office estimates the shutdown will result in $7-14 billion in permanent GDP loss. The suspension of key economic data releases creates a â€œdata black hole,â€ forcing the Federal Reserve to formulate policy without core data on employment, inflation, etc. Approximately 750,000 federal employees have been furloughed, and SNAP (food stamp) benefits will cease on November 1, further impacting consumer demand.

  • Hedge Volatility:

  • Risk Management:

    • Position Sizing: Total tech position not exceeding 50%, single sector not exceeding 25%.
    • Cash: Retain 15%-20% for pullback opportunities.

VI. Conclusion and Outlook

Section titled â€œVI. Conclusion and Outlookâ€
  • November is a critical watershed: Tariff rulings, AI leader earnings, and the Fedâ€™s path will shape Q4 and 2026 landscape.
  • AI investment differentiation: Infrastructure and platforms with real revenue and customers offer more certainty.
  • Policy uncertainty becomes the norm: Need to adapt to increased volatility.
  • Valuation is elevated but not a full bubble: Risks concentrated in extremely overvalued individual stocks and some startups.
  • Recommendation: â€œ70% Defensive + 30% Offensiveâ€: Quality leaders and hedging tools as foundation, supplemented by event-driven opportunities.

November Timeline

  • 11/4 (Tuesday): AMD Earnings â†’ AI chip competitive landscape
  • 11/5 (Wednesday): Supreme Court Tariff Argument â†’ Trade direction signals

  • 12/9-10: FOMC Meeting â†’ Clarification of rate cut path

Current market presents both opportunities and risks. Maintain discipline with data and logic, exercise moderate restraint in a â€œlow volatility + high valuationâ€ environment. Warren Buffettâ€™s famous quote is worth noting: â€œBe fearful when others are greedy, and greedy when others are fearful.â€

item.title: From Exploration to Fix: How Claude Code Thinks and Reasons Through a SQLAlchemy Transaction Rollback Issue
item.content:encoded:
This technical blog is distilled from a real production incident investigation. It focuses on how Claude Code â€œexplores â†’ thinks â†’ reasonsâ€ to quickly pinpoint the root cause, ship the smallest viable fix, and propose followâ€‘up structural improvements.

The problem occurred in the mailflow service in production. The core error was:

From the surrounding logs, the failure happened when executing an INSERT into the emails table. Subsequent database operations then entered a â€œcascade failureâ€ state.

1. Context and Goals

Section titled â€œ1. Context and Goalsâ€
  • Context: While handling inbound emails (parsing, creating records, forwarding, moving IMAP folders), mailflow occasionally fails the entire processing chain.
  • Goals:
    • Identify the primary trigger of the transaction failure;
    • Explain why all subsequent DB operations report the same error;
    • Restore processing with the smallest, lowestâ€‘risk change;
    • Provide structural improvement suggestions to increase robustness.

2. Exploration Path: From Symptoms to Evidence

Section titled â€œ2. Exploration Path: From Symptoms to Evidenceâ€

Leveraging Claude Codeâ€™s code search and crossâ€‘context capabilities, we proceeded â€œfrom symptoms to root causeâ€ in order:

  • Locking onto logs and trigger point

    • The logs show the exception stems from the SQLAlchemy Session state: after a prior transaction failure, rollback() was not performed, leaving the current Session invalid.

  • Locating key code paths

    • mailflow/app/db.py: connection and session factory definitions.
    • mailflow/app/mail.py: main business flow, record creation, and commit points.
    • mailflow/app/utils.py: logging and WeCom notification entry notify_and_log.

  • Evidence 1: Moduleâ€‘level global Session

    • At the top of mail.py there is:
    • Once any flush/commit fails, this global Session becomes invalid, and all subsequent DB operations that rely on it will fail until an explicit session.rollback() is issued.

  • Evidence 2: Missing exception handling and rollback

    • Multiple session.commit() calls lack try/except/rollback protection:
      • Creating the mail record (create_mail)
      • Relating attachments to mail (_relation_attachment_and_mail)
      • Updating status when dealing with request results (deal_requests_result)
      • Large sections of the main flow in process_mail

Conclusion: The first failed DB operation puts the global Session into an invalid state. Because rollback() is missing, all later commits and even queries on that path fail with the same error, forming a â€œcascade failureâ€.

3. Reasoning Chain: From Hypothesis to Verification

Section titled â€œ3. Reasoning Chain: From Hypothesis to Verificationâ€

  1. Hypothesis: An INSERT/UPDATE exception (possibly from data constraints, transient network issues, or the pool) invalidates the global Session; without rollback(), subsequent steps (status updates, attachment relations, mail moves) all fail.

  2. Code verification:

    • Found the global session = session_factory();
    • Searched for session.commit() call sites â€” most lack except: session.rollback();
    • This matches the error semantics exactly.

  3. Strategy: Move fast with minimal change to restore stability first, then evaluate structural refactoring.

4. Fix Strategy and Implementation

Section titled â€œ4. Fix Strategy and Implementationâ€

We prioritized the fix in three levels (P0 â†’ P2):

  • P0 (immediate, smallest change): add session.rollback() in exception handlers so the Session can selfâ€‘recover.
  • P1 (comprehensive guard): wrap every commit() with try/except/rollback to avoid any single failure taking down the rest of the flow.
  • P2 (structural): replace the moduleâ€‘level global Session with scoped_session to isolate session state across processing flows (recommended, not mandatory for the hotfix).

4.1 Key Patch Snippets

Section titled â€œ4.1 Key Patch Snippetsâ€
  • Add rollback in the main flow (mailflow/app/mail.py)
  • Guard status updates when handling request results (wrap both success and failure branches)
  • Guard establishing mailâ€“attachment relations
  • Add protection for creating the mail record create_mail

4.2 Structural Optimization (P2)

Section titled â€œ4.2 Structural Optimization (P2)â€

Eliminate the risk where a â€œglobal Session drags down all flowsâ€ by using scoped_session:

Note: scoped_session provides better isolation in concurrent/multithreaded environments and reduces crossâ€‘request contamination. The production hotfix first ensures rollback semantics are correct and complete; then evaluate the migration cost/benefit.

5. Validation and Regression

Section titled â€œ5. Validation and Regressionâ€

Suggested validation steps:

  • Single reproducible mail replay: replay a previously failing mail and observe whether the chain recovers;
  • Observe logs: the message â€œCanâ€™t reconnect until invalid transaction is rolled backâ€ should no longer appear;
  • Manual spotâ€‘check: verify IMAP folder moves, forwarding, and database state;
  • Controlled load: increase the number of sample mails to ensure multiple commit points correctly roll back and continue.

6. Lessons Learned and Best Practices

Section titled â€œ6. Lessons Learned and Best Practicesâ€
  • Antiâ€‘pattern: a moduleâ€‘level global Session, once invalid, causes chainâ€‘wide cascade failures.
  • Principle: every commit() should be wrapped by try/except + rollback; also rollback() in the topâ€‘level exception handler of the main flow.
  • Design: adopt a failureâ€‘resilient session model (scoped_session or acquire/release per processing unit).
  • Operations: log and alert immediately (this project uses WeCom via notify_and_log), and include key identifiers (uid, subject, time, to_list) in the message.

7. Claude Codeâ€™s Methodology

Section titled â€œ7. Claude Codeâ€™s Methodologyâ€

This â€œexplore â†’ reason â†’ fixâ€ path generalizes to most codeâ€‘level issues:

  1. Quickly bound the problem: start from the error semantics and match the most likely layer (transaction/session management).
  2. Evidenceâ€‘driven search: find the relevant files, variables, and functions (session_factory, commit() call sites).
  3. Hypothesize â†’ falsify/corroborate: propose â€œglobal Session + no rollback â†’ cascade failureâ€, then find direct evidence in code.
  4. Smallest change first: add rollback() so the Session can recover and stop the bleeding.
  5. Structural improvement: propose scoped_session as the followâ€‘up path, balancing benefit and migration cost.

There is an analyst AI, an architect AI, a developer AI, a tester AIâ€”each playing a role so that planning, coding, and testing all get staged like a full production. BMAD ships with a CLI and a web UI, plus special â€œscript filesâ€ and context management so the AI team can collaborate. It usually unfolds in two phases: first the â€œanalyst/product manager/architectâ€ agents do the planning and design, then the â€œScrum Master/developerâ€ agents write the actual code. The upside is a thorough workflow that stays orderlyâ€”ideal for large, complex projects that demand clear documentation and division of labor. The downside is that it is cumbersome to use, has a steep learning curve, and expects the underlying model to truly understand the documentation you write.

Spec-Kit â€“ an open-source utility on GitHub that layers a bit of â€œprocessâ€ on top of your existing AI coding assistant. Developers use the command line to nudge AI through a â€œSpecification â†’ Plan â†’ Tasks â†’ Implementationâ€ four-step. In short, Spec-Kit asks you to nail the requirements first, then guides AI to break work down and produce code. It turns your specification markdown into an â€œexecutable documentâ€ using commands like /specify, /plan, and /tasks. It is lightweight and flexible, does not force you to revamp your workflow, and is model-agnostic. Great for solo builders or small teams that want to add structure and improve AI-generated code quality.

OpenSpec â€“ a minimalist newcomer that believes â€œsimple is better.â€ You write a slim Markdown spec and pair it with a handful of commands to finish the job. Its flow has only three steps: submit a change proposal, let AI produce the task list, then let AI apply the spec to modify the code. The highlight is efficiency: the specs stay lean, token usage stays low, and there is barely any metadata. It works well for individuals or small teams chasing extreme speedâ€”minor tweaks get done in minutes. The trade-off is that model support is still limited, but it is so easy to learn that there is almost no overhead.

Spot the pattern? These tools share the same philosophy: document first, then drive the AI. The goal is to reduce the uncertainty of vibe coding by giving AI a clear rulebook so code quality becomes controllable. Ideal in theoryâ€”but reality bites. If you are not careful, the documentation you create can morph into another giant spaghetti pile. Why does that happen? Read on.

Four Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Faster

Section titled â€œFour Reasons Documentation Turns into a Spaghetti Mountain Even Fasterâ€

1. Lack of Structure

Section titled â€œ1. Lack of Structureâ€

Code is constrained by syntaxâ€”one misplaced comma and it will not even run. Documentation is much freer, and AI is not human. When a model stares at free-form, meandering text, its comprehension goes sideways. Code is deterministic; specifications are often vague and open to interpretation. If your documentation is loosely structured, the AI sees the world through fogged glass, and it is no surprise when the code it generates veers off in the wrong direction.

2. Inconsistent AI Understanding

Section titled â€œ2. Inconsistent AI Understandingâ€

Even if you write a decent document, there is no guarantee the AI will interpret it the same way every time. Seasoned developers know the saying â€œa thousand readers, a thousand Hamletsâ€â€”and AI thinks even more differently from humans. ChatGPT might implement the feature correctly today, but a different model tomorrow could distort your intent. Documentation lacks the compilerâ€™s safety net, so misunderstandings can hide in plain sight and quietly plant landmines.

3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errors

Section titled â€œ3. AI Hallucinations Amplify Errorsâ€

We all know large language models hallucinateâ€”confidently fabricating details. When AI uses incomplete or ambiguous documentation to write code, the stakes rise. Miss a detail in your spec and the AI might â€œfill in the gapsâ€ with something that looks plausible but is wrong. Worse still, if that flawed AI-generated documentation or code gets reused later, another AI might treat it as gospel truth. Errors balloon like rumors: once they make it into formal docs, people and models alike will keep getting misled.

4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselves

Section titled â€œ4. New Risks Introduced by the Tools Themselvesâ€

Finally, consider the complexity of the tools. Adopting Spec-Kit or BMAD might require extra software and brand-new rituals. You can end up wrestling with tooling, pouring hours into crafting specs and calibrating workflows, while actual coding time shrinks. If you do not internalize the framework, you may copy templates mechanically, letting documentation drift away from the code. Like wielding a scalpel without trainingâ€”the damage can be greater than doing nothing.

How to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Tools

Section titled â€œHow to Avoid the Pile-Up: A Tiered Playbook for Documentation Toolsâ€

The pitfalls sound daunting, but do not lose heart. With a tiered usage strategy, documentation-driven programming can still pave a smoother road:

Use direct prompts for tiny tweaks

Section titled â€œUse direct prompts for tiny tweaksâ€

When you are only adjusting a small logic branch or styling tweak, there is no need to assemble a grand spec. In these cases, asking Claude Code, Codex, Gemini, GitHub Copilot, or Cursor directly is fastest. Explain the request in a sentence or two and let the AI offer a diff or snippet. You save time and stay focused. As veterans like to say: small asks do not need the full ceremony; if a quick chat solves it, skip the paperwork.

Reach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changes

Section titled â€œReach for Spec-Kit or OpenSpec on medium-sized changesâ€

If you are adding a mid-sized featureâ€”multiple steps, not massiveâ€”consider a lightweight tool such as Spec-Kit or OpenSpec. Spend ten minutes drafting an MVP-level spec that captures key requirements and edge cases, then hand it to the AI to refine the plan and tasks. Spec-Kit decomposes work item by item; OpenSpec minimizes context switching and handles the change in a few commands. The key is to keep the spec concise, covering only what is necessary. Data shows that compact specs are easier for AI to execute faithfully and more efficient overall. Once the feature ships, remember to update canonical docs or clean up temporary specs to prevent outdated information from piling up.

Deploy BMAD for major overhauls

Section titled â€œDeploy BMAD for major overhaulsâ€

For large-scale refactors or brand-new complex subsystemsâ€”the real â€œsurgeryâ€â€”you need a rigorous approach. This is where a multi-agent framework like BMAD earns its keep: it orchestrates end-to-end planning, architecture, and task allocation. Think of it as hiring a virtual AI team to keep big projects on the rails. Of course, humans must stay in the loopâ€”never blindly accept each AI output; review and adjust. Before spinning up BMAD, weigh the costs: it takes time and demands strong model comprehension. That investment can pay off for long-lived initiatives, but the documentation it producesâ€”specs, user stories, and moreâ€”should evolve with the code. Do not toss it aside after one run; maintain it alongside the project or you will be rebuilding from scratch next time.

No matter the scale, remember the â€œdocumentation MVPâ€ principle: the doc should cover only what is necessary and true right now. Do not chase completeness for its own sake. Many veterans delete temporary specs once a feature is done because the code itself is already clear. Instead of hoarding outdated notes that mislead people, keep a lean, accurate reference and update it as the product evolves. Documentation earns its value by reflecting reality; once it drifts, it is just dead weight.

Conclusion

Section titled â€œConclusionâ€

Documentation-driven programming is a double-edged sword in the AI era. Used well, it makes development more efficient and orderly; misused, it spawns fresh spaghetti mountains. Ambitious young engineers should absolutely explore new tools, but not worship them blindly. Whether we are talking code or docs, the heart of the matter is understanding the requirement and keeping information current. Whenever you decide to write a spec or pick a tool, ask yourself: â€œIs this making the problem clearerâ€”or just adding complexity?â€

Hereâ€™s to every developer mastering these AI tools, producing docs that stay crisp and useful, and turning documentation into an assetâ€”not a burden. We all want higher productivity, not a literal spaghetti mountain blocking the office! ğŸ’©
